verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:1
verses.text: Epistle XX.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:2
verses.text: St.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:3
verses.text: Ambrose relates to his sister the events at Milan connected with the demand of the Arians for a basilica, and how the people rose up in opposition.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:4
verses.text: Then that on the second day the basilica had been occupied by soldiers, who however fraternized with the Catholics.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:5
verses.text: He gives a sketch of his address, comparing their trials to those of Job, more particularly those caused by his wife, and other cases owing to women.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:6
verses.text: Though the basilica was surrendered, he himself had been threatened by a notary, but this did not trouble him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:7
verses.text: He adapts the story of Jonah to the present circumstances, relates the joy of the people at recovering their church, Valentinian's words to his courtiers, and the behaviour of Calligonus to himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:8
verses.text: The date of the letter is Easter, a.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:9
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:12
verses.text: Since in almost all your letters you enquire anxiously about the Church, you shall hear what is taking place.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:13
verses.text: The day after I received your letter, in which you said you were troubled by dreams, the pressure of heavy troubles began to be felt.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:14
verses.text: And this time it was not the Portian basilica, that is the one outside the walls, which was demanded, but the new basilica, that is the one within the walls, which is larger.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:16
verses.text: First of all some great men, counsellors of state, begged of me to give up the basilica, and to manage that the people should make no disturbance.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:17
verses.text: I replied, of course, that the temple of God could not be surrendered by a Bishop.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:19
verses.text: On the following day this answer was approved by the people in the Church; and  the Prefect came there, and began to persuade us to give up at least the Portian basilica, but the people clamoured against it.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:20
verses.text: He then went away implying that he should report to the Emperor.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:22
verses.text: The day after, which was Sunday, after the lessons and the sermon, when the Catechumens were dismissed, I was teaching the creed to certain candidates in the baptistery of the basilica.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:23
verses.text: There it was reported to me that they had sent decani from the palace, and were putting up hangings, and that part of the people were going there.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:24
verses.text: I, however, remained at my ministrations, and began to celebrate mass.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:26
verses.text: Whilst offering the oblation, I heard that a certain Castulus, who, the Arians said, was a priest, had been seized by the people.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:27
verses.text: Passers-by had come upon him in the streets.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:28
verses.text: I began to weep bitterly, and to implore God in the oblation that He would come to our aid, and that no one's blood be shed in the Church's cause, or at least that it might be my blood shed for the benefit not of my people only, but also for the unbelievers themselves.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:29
verses.text: Not to say more, I sent priests and deacons and rescued the man from violence.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:31
verses.text: Thereupon the heaviest sentences were decreed, first upon the whole body of merchants.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:32
verses.text: And so during the holy days of the last week of Lent, when usually the bonds of debtors are loosed, chains were heard grating, were being placed on the necks of innocent persons, and two hundred pounds' weight of gold was required within three days' time.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:33
verses.text: They replied that they would give as much or twice as much, if demanded, so that only they might preserve their faith.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:34
verses.text: The prisons were full of trades-people.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:36
verses.text: All the officials of the palace, that is the recorders, the commissioners, the apparitors of the different magistrates, were commanded to keep away from what was going on, on the pretence that they were forbidden to take part in any sedition; many very heavy penalties were threatened against men of position, if they did not surrender the basilica.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:37
verses.text: Persecution was raging, and had they but opened the floodgates, they seemed likely to break out into every kind of violence.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:39
verses.text: The Counts and Tribunes came and urged me to cause the basilica to be quickly surrendered, saying that the Emperor was exercising his rights since everything was under his power.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:40
verses.text: I answered that if he asked of me what was mine, that is, my land, my money, or whatever of this kind was my own, I would not refuse it, although all that I have belonged to the poor, but that those things which are God's are not subject to the imperial power.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:41
verses.text: "If my patrimony is required, enter upon it, if my body, I will go at once.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:42
verses.text: Do you wish to cast me into chains, or to give me to death? it will be a pleasure to me.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:43
verses.text: I will not defend myself with throngs of people, nor will I cling to the altars and entreat for my life, but will more gladly be slain myself for the altars".

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:45
verses.text: I was indeed struck with horror when I learnt that armed men had been sent to take possession of the basilica, lest while the people were defending the basilica, there might be some slaughter which would tend to the injury of the whole city.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:46
verses.text: I prayed that I might not survive the destruction of so great a city, or it might be of the whole of Italy.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:47
verses.text: I feared the odium of shedding blood, I offered my own neck.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:48
verses.text: Some Gothic tribunes were present, whom I accosted, and said, "Have you received the gift of Roman rights in order to make yourselves disturbers of the public peace? Whither will you go, if things here are destroyed?"  10.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:49
verses.text: Then I was desired to restrain the people; I answered that it was in my power not to excite them; but in God's hands to quiet them.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:50
verses.text: And that if they thought that I was urging them on, they ought at once to punish me, or that I ought to be sent to any desert part of the earth they chose.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:51
verses.text: After I had said this, they departed, and I spent the whole day in the old basilica, and thence went home to sleep, that if any one wanted to carry me off he might find me ready.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:53
verses.text: Before day when I left the house the basilica was surrounded by soldiers.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:54
verses.text: It is said that the soldiers had intimated to the Emperor that if he wished to go forth he could do so; that they would be in attendance, if they saw him go to join the Catholics; if not that they would go to the assembly which Ambrose had convened.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:56
verses.text: None of the Arians dared to go forth, for there was not one among the citizens, only a few of the royal family, and some of the Goths.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:57
verses.text: And they as of old they made  use of their waggons as dwellings, now make the Church their waggon.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:58
verses.text: Wherever that woman goes, she carries with her all assemblage.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:60
verses.text: I heard that the Basilica was surrounded by the groaning of the people, but whilst the lessons were being read, I was informed that the new Basilica also was full of people, that the crowd seemed greater than when they were all free, and that a Reader was being called for.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:61
verses.text: In short, the soldiers themselves who seemed to have occupied the Basilica, when they knew that I had ordered that the people should abstain from communion with them, began to come to our assembly.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:62
verses.text: When they saw this, the minds of the women were troubled, and one rushed forth.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:63
verses.text: But the soldiers themselves said that they had come for prayer not for fighting.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:64
verses.text: The people uttered some cries.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:65
verses.text: With great moderation, with great instancy, with great faithfulness they begged that we would go to that Basilica.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:66
verses.text: It was said, too, that the people in that Basilica were demanding my presence.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:68
verses.text: I then commenced the following address.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:69
verses.text: You have heard, my children, the reading of the book of Job, which, according to the appointed order and season, is being gone through.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:70
verses.text: By experience the devil also knew that this book would be explained, in which all the power of his temptations is shown and made clear, and so to-day he roused himself with greater vigour.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:71
verses.text: But thanks be to our God, who has so established you with faith and patience.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:72
verses.text: I had mounted the pulpit to praise Job alone, and I have found in you all Jobs to praise.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:73
verses.text: In each of you Job lives again, in each the patience and valour of that saint has shone forth again.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:74
verses.text: For what more resolute could have been said by Christian men, than what the Holy Spirit has to-day spoken in you? We request, O Augustus, we do not fight, we do not fear, but we request.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:75
verses.text: This beseems Christians both to wish for peace and tranquillity, and not to suffer constancy of faith and truth to be checked by fear.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:76
verses.text: For the Lord is our Leader, "Who is the Saviour of them that hope in Him".

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:78
verses.text: But let us come to the lessons before us.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:79
verses.text: You see that permission is given to the devil, that the good may be tested.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:80
verses.text: The evil one envies all progress in good, he tempts us in divers way.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:81
verses.text: He tried holy Job in his possessions, in his children, in pain of body.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:82
verses.text: The stronger is tried in his own person, the weaker in that of another.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:83
verses.text: And he was desirous of carrying off my riches which I possess in you, and wished to dissipate this patrimony of your tranquillity.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:84
verses.text: And he strove to deprive me of yourselves also, my good children, for whom I daily renew the Sacrifice, you he endeavoured to involve in the ruin as it were of a public disturbance.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:85
verses.text: I have then already been assailed by two kinds of temptation.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:86
verses.text: And perhaps because the Lord our God knows me to be too weak, He has not yet given him power over my body.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:87
verses.text: Though myself may desire it, though I offer myself, He deems me yet it may be unequal to this conflict, and exercises me with divers labours.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:88
verses.text: And Job did not begin with that conflict but finished with it.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:90
verses.text: But Job was tried by accumulated tidings of evils, he was also tried by his wife, who said, "Speak a word against God and die".

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:91
verses.text: You see what terrible things are of a sudden stirred up, the Goths, armed men, the heathen, the fines of the merchants, the sufferings of the Saints.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:92
verses.text: You observe what was commanded, when the order was given "surrender the Basilica;" that is "speak a word against God and die.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:93
verses.text: And not only, speak against God," but, Do something against Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:94
verses.text: For the command was, surrender the altars of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:96
verses.text: So, then, we are prepared by the imperial commands, but are strengthened by the words of Scripture, which replies: "Thou hast spoken as one of the foolish".

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:97
verses.text: That temptation then is no light one, for, we know that those temptations are more severe which arise through women.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:98
verses.text: For even Adam was overthrown by Eve, whereby it came to pass that he erred from the Divine commandments.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:99
verses.text: And when he recognized his error, feeling the reproach of a guilty conscience, he would fain have hidden himself, but he could not be hidden, and so God said to him: "Adam, where art thou?" that is, what wast thou before? where hast thou now begun to be? Where had I placed thee? Whither hast thou wandered? Thou ownest that thou art naked because thou hast lost the robe of a good faith.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:100
verses.text: Those are leaves with which thou now seekest to veil thyself.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:101
verses.text: Thou hast rejected the fruit, thou desired to hide under the leaves of the Law, but thou art betrayed.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:102
verses.text: Thou hast desired to depart from the Lord thy God for the sake of one woman, therefore thou fleest from Him Whom thou soughtest before to see.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:103
verses.text: Thou hast chosen  to hide thyself with one woman, to forsake the Mirror of the world, the abode in Paradise, the grace of Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:105
verses.text: Why should I relate that Jezebel, also persecuted Elisha after a bloodthirsty fashion? or that Herodias caused John the Baptist to be slain? Individuals persecuted individuals; but for me, whose merits are far inferior, the trials are all the harder.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:106
verses.text: My strength is less, but I have more danger.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:107
verses.text: Of women change follows on change, their hatreds alternate, their falsehoods vary, elders assemble together, wrong done to the Emperor is made a pretence.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:108
verses.text: What is then the reason of such severe temptation against me, a mere worm; except that they are attacking not me but the Church?  19.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:109
verses.text: At last the command was given: Surrender the Basilica.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:110
verses.text: My reply was, it is not lawful for me to surrender it, nor advantageous for you, O Emperor, to receive it.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:111
verses.text: By no right can you violate the house of a private person, and do you think that the House of God may be taken away? It is asserted that everything is lawful for the Emperor, that all things are his.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:112
verses.text: My answer is: Do not, O Emperor, lay on yourself the burden of such a thought as that you have any imperial power over those things which belong to God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:113
verses.text: Exalt not yourself, but if you desire to reign long, submit yourself to God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:114
verses.text: It is written: "The things which are God's to God, those which are Caesar's to Caesar".

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:115
verses.text: The palaces belong to the Emperor, the churches to the Bishop.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:116
verses.text: Authority is committed to you over public, not over sacred buildings.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:117
verses.text: Again the Emperor was stated to have declared: I also ought to have one Basilica.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:118
verses.text: My answer was: It is not lawful for you to have it.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:119
verses.text: What have you to do with an adulteress? For she is an adulteress who is not joined to Christ in lawful wedlock.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:121
verses.text: Whilst I was treating on this matter, tidings were brought me that the royal hangings were taken down, and the Basilica filled with people, who were calling for my presence, so I at once turned my discourse to this, and said: How high and how deep are the oracles of the Holy Spirit! We said at Matins, as you, brethren, remember, and made the response with the greatest grief of mind: "O God, the heathen are come into Thine inheritance".

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:122
verses.text: And in very deed the heathen came, and even worse than the heathen came; for the Goths came, and men of different nations; they came with weapons and surrounded and occupied the Basilica.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:123
verses.text: We in our ignorance of Thy greatness mourned over this, but our want of foresight was in error.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:125
verses.text: The heathen are come, and in very truth are come into Thine inheritance, for they who came as heathen have become Christians.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:126
verses.text: Those who came to invade Thine inheritance, have been made coheirs with God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:127
verses.text: I have those as protectors whom I considered to be adversaries.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:128
verses.text: That is fulfilled which the Prophet sang of the Lord Jesus that "His dwelling is in peace," and "There brake He the horns of the bows, the shield, the sword and the battle".

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:129
verses.text: For whose gift is this, whose work is this but Thine, Lord Jesus? Thou sawest armed men coming to Thy temple; on the one hand the people wailing and coming in throngs so as not to seem to surrender the Basilica of God, on the other hand the soldiers ordered to use violence.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:130
verses.text: Death was before my eyes, lest madness should gain any footing whilst things were thus.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:131
verses.text: Thou, O Lord, didst come between, and madest of twain one.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:132
verses.text: Thou didst restrain the armed men, saying, If ye run together to arms, if those shut up in My temple are troubled, "what profit is there in My blood".

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:133
verses.text: Thanks then be unto Thee, O Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:134
verses.text: No ambassador, no messenger, but Thou, O Lord, hast saved Thy people, "Thou hast put off my sackcloth and girded me with gladness".

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:136
verses.text: I said these things, wondering that the Emperor's mind could be softened by the zeal of the soldiers, the entreaties of the Counts, and the supplication of the people.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:137
verses.text: Meanwhile I was told that a notary had been sent to me, to bring me orders.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:138
verses.text: I retired a little, and he intimated the order to me.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:139
verses.text: What were you thinking of, he said, in acting against the Emperor's decree? I replied: I do not know what has been decreed, and I have not been informed of what has been unadvisedly done.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:140
verses.text: He asked: Why did you send priests to the Basilica? If you are a tyrant I wish to know it, that I may know how to prepare against you.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:141
verses.text: I replied by saying that I had done nothing hastily regarding the Church.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:142
verses.text: That at the time when I heard that the Basilica was occupied by soldiers,  I only gave freer utterance to groans, and that when many were exhorting me to go thither, I said: I cannot surrender the basilica, but I may not fight.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:143
verses.text: But after I heard that the royal hangings had been taken away, when the people were urging me to go thither, I sent some priests; that I would not go myself, but said, I believe in Christ that the Emperor himself will treat with us.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:145
verses.text: If these acts looked like tyranny, that I had arms, but only in the Name of Christ, that I had the power of offering my own body.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:146
verses.text: Why, I said, did he delay to strike, if he thought me a tyrant? That by ancient right imperial power had been given by bishops, never assumed, and it was commonly said that emperors had desired the priesthood, rather than priests the imperial power.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:147
verses.text: That Christ withdrew lest He should be made a king.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:148
verses.text: That we had our own power; for the power of a bishop was his weakness.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:149
verses.text: "When I am weak," says the Apostle, "then I become strong".

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:150
verses.text: But let him against whom God has not stirred up an adversary beware lest he make a tyrant for himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:151
verses.text: That Maximus did not say that I was the tyrant of Valentinian, he complained that by the intervention of my legation he had been unable to cross over into Italy.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:152
verses.text: And I added that priests had never been tyrants, but had often suffered from them.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:154
verses.text: We passed that whole day in sadness, but the imperial hangings were cut by boys in derision.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:155
verses.text: I could not return home, because the soldiers who were guarding the basilica were all around.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:156
verses.text: We repeated Psalms with the brethren in the smaller basilica of the Church.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:158
verses.text: On the following day the Book of Jonah was read according to custom, after the completion of which I began this discourse.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:159
verses.text: A book has been read, brethren, in which it is foretold that sinners shall be converted.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:160
verses.text: Their acceptance takes place because that which is to happen is looked forward to at present.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:161
verses.text: I added that the just man had been willing even to incur blame, in order not to see or denounce the destruction of the city.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:162
verses.text: And because the sentence was mournful he was also saddened that the gourd had withered up.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:163
verses.text: God too said to the prophet: "Art thou sad because of the gourd?" and Jonah answered: "I am sad".

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:164
verses.text: And the Lord then said, that if he grieved that the gourd was withered, how much should He Himself care for the salvation of so many people.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:165
verses.text: And therefore that He had put away the destruction which had been prepared for the whole city.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:167
verses.text: And without further delay, tidings are brought that the Emperor had commanded the soldiers to retire from the basilica, and that the sums which had been exacted of the merchants should be restored.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:168
verses.text: How great then was the joy of the whole people! how just their applause! and how abundant their thanks! And it was the day on which the Lord was delivered up for us, on which penance is relaxed in the Church.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:169
verses.text: The soldiers vied with each other in bringing in these tidings, rushing to the altars, giving kisses, the mark of peace.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:170
verses.text: Then I recognized that God had smitten the early worm that the whole city might be preserved.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:172
verses.text: These things were done, and would that all was at an end! but the Emperor's words full of excitement foreshadow future and worse troubles.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:173
verses.text: I am called a tyrant, and even more than a tyrant.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:174
verses.text: For when the Counts were entreating the Emperor to go to the Church, and said that they were doing this at the request of the soldiers, he answered: If Ambrose bade you, you would deliver me up to him in chains.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:175
verses.text: You can think what may be coming after these words.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:176
verses.text: All shuddered when they heard them, but he has some by whom he is exasperated.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:178
verses.text: Lastly, too, Calligonus, the chief chamberlain, ventured to address me in peculiar language.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:179
verses.text: Do you, said he, whilst I am alive treat Valentinian with contempt? I will take your head from you.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:180
verses.text: My reply was, God grant you to fulfil your threat; for then I shall suffer as bishops do, you will act as do eunuchs.

verses.name: Ambrose: Epistle XX 1:181
verses.text: Would that God might turn them away from the Church, let them direct all their weapons against me, let them satisfy their thirst with my blood.
